name: Rabbit of Caerbonn (ROC)
description:
Introduction

Originally named Little Canyon in the Kelsey canyoneering book... "The name was so mundane we felt a better name was in order. Mike Schasch named the canyon ROC (short for Rabbit of Caerbannog) after the guardian of a cave in a Monty Python movie. The Rabbit of Caerbannog appears to be a small, cute little thing that could do no harm. After a short engagement with the ROC the soldiers find the rabbit to unimaginably fierce, swift and deadly. ROC canyon is small and goes almost un-noticed but it is quite the deep skinny crack that has a serious bite."

Approach

Descent

Exit

Trip reports and media

Background

properties.name: tDryFork
properties.description: Dry Fork Trail Head. Follow the trail going north leaving the parking area. After about 400 feet the trail will fade away where you will find a steep slope of slick rock. Route find your way northwest down the slick rock down to the flat desert floor below. After getting to the bottom of the steep slick rock slope; route find your way north about 700 feet over to the top of a deep side drainage dropping northeast down into DryFork of Coyote Gulch. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: yROC-Tp
properties.description: Top entry to ROC Canyon (aka Kelsey's Little Canyon). This is where ROC starts into a skiny slot. The next 950 feet of canyon is a mix of squeezing between the walls on the canyon floor and stemming / galumphing down canyon up off the canyon floor where it is too skinny to stay low. Depending on your size and comfort level you may be up to 30 feet off the deck at times. Some of the stemming is straight forward with a lot of features to make travel easy and other parts of the stemming involve navigating between near vertical walls with few features and lots of rotten rock to break away. There are also a few gapers to cross over that are not very wide but serious fall potential if mistakes are made. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: ROC-03
properties.description: End of the Upper slot of ROC where you will be able to walk in semi wide open sand floor for about 500 feet to the start of another slot. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: ROC-04
properties.description: End of a walking section and starting into another slot. This last slot is about 200 feet long and travels quick and easy with one vertical drop about 8 feet that is easily partner assisted shortlybefore reaching the end of ROC. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: yROC-BT
properties.description: Bottom of ROC canyon (aka Kelsey's Little Canyon). This is where the slot dumps out into a sandy area in Dry Fork of Coyote Gulch. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: jBrimstoneLwr
properties.description: Bottom of the Brimstone Canyon drainage where it dumps into Dry Fork. There is large sandstone hill about 200 feet wide at the confluence which you can walk around either side to start up Brimstone. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: DryFork74
properties.description: Down canyon end of a walk through slot in Dry Fork about 850 feet long. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: DryFork73
properties.description: Up canyon end of a walk through slot in Dry Fork about 850 feet long. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: DryFork72
properties.description: Down canyon end of a walk through slot in Dry Fork about 400 feet long. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: DryFork71
properties.description: Up canyon end of a walk through slot in Dry Fork about 400 feet long. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: jSpookyBt
properties.description: Confluence of the Dry Fork wash and the bottom of the Spooky draiange. To continue down Dry Fork to go to Brimstone or ROC continue east down the wash. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: jFrk2Spooky
properties.description: Fork to Spooky Slot Canyon. This is a little short cut over to the bottom of the Spooky Slot. The actual drainage for Spooky joins Dry Fork about 0.3 miles east of here on the side trail to the left. To continue down Dry Fork stay right and stay in the main wash as it bends right. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: yPeek-A-BooBt
properties.description: Bottom of Peek-A-Boo Slot Canyon. A visual clue to know you are at the bottom of Peek-a-Boo slot is looking up at it you will see a need to climb up in it to get to the slot above (this is in contrast to the bottom of Spooky Slot where you can walk into the bottom). (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: wDryForkRP-02
properties.description: Down in Dry Fork after dropping in from the Dry Fork Trailhead. Turn right to walk east(ish) down canyon in the Dry Fork drainage. About 250 feet down canyon is the bottom exit of the Peek-A- Boo slot (yPeek-A-BooBt) which will be on the left (north) side of the wash. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: wDryForkRP-01
properties.description: Head of a deep slot/ drainage dropping down into Dry Fork. Follow down into this drainage for about 0.16 miles where you will find yourself in the Dry Fork Drainage. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: extDryForkTH2
properties.description: Junction where road 252 goes left (north) to Dry Fork trailhead. Continuing straight (east) follows an un-named road to an un-named TH about 1.5 miles away. Along the un-named road ther are a few places to camp and about 0.8 miles in the road gets deeper with sand and has more rough rock making passenger cars a bad idea. (Data by bluugnome.com)

properties.name: extDryForkTH1
properties.description: Turn off of Hole-In-The-Rock road toward Dry Fork trailhead. BLM road 252 (Data by bluugnome.com)
